dt: {bc}a summons or strong inclination to a particular state or course of action
{bc}a divine call to the religious life
{bc}an entry into the priesthood or a religious order
{bc}the work in which a person is employed {bc}{sx|occupation||}
{bc}the persons engaged in a particular occupation
{bc}the special function of an individual or group

et: Middle English {it}vocacioun{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}vocaciun{/it}, from Latin {it}vocation-, vocatio{/it} summons, from {it}vocare{/it} to call, from {it}vox{/it} voice {ma}{mat|voice|}{/ma}
shortdef: a summons or strong inclination to a particular state or course of action; especially : a divine call to the religious life
an entry into the priesthood or a religious order
the work in which a person is employed : occupation

dt: {bc}to not have the career one should have

dt.t: He feels he {it}missed his vocation{/it} by not becoming a doctor.

shortdef: to not have the career one should have
